Joe hasn’t been home to Smoky Hollow in a long time. But one day Granny gets a letter with (another) promise from Joe, that he will be home for Christmas.“The Christmas Quilt” is not as much a story about a quilt as it is about growing up in Smoky Hollow. Granny, the mainstay of the family, is ill. After she receives her latest letter with Joe’s promise, she decides to start a quilt for him.I really enjoyed this quietly told, warm Christmas story. Told from the perspective of the main character, a 12 year old boy growing up in the Smoky Mts, each chapter reminisces a down-home mountain memory. There is a variety of both small and large events in a country boy's life; both good and bad. There are stories of summer-time, of hard work and hard play. There are stories about baptisms in the creek, and church suppers, picking blackberries and harvesting the apples. And there is good old-fashioned American ‘make-do with what you got’. After all, who ever invented tree stands? who needs a tree stand when you have the outdoors and a barn?“Daddy told Mildred to go and fetch some water from out back, and while she did that Daddy placed the bucket in front of the window, and the two of us placed the tree in the bucket. Daddy had cut it just right – there wouldn’t be any need to cut any of the lower branches to make it fit in. Mildred came back with the water, and Daddy poured it in. Then Daddy said, “You two go and fetch some rocks now, and I’ll make shore the tree don’t git up and walk away.” So we did that, too, same as every Christmas I could remember since I stood big enough to gather up rocks and bring them in. Mildred and I went back to the barn, got another bucket, and went to pick some of the good-sized rocks up in our road and up near the main road, filling the bucket almost full – it didn’t need to be all the way full, because the tree trunk would take up some room.Doing something for Christmas like we were doing made the work seem more like fun. We practically ran back to the house with our rocks, feeling all good about them like it was something special to be able to pick up rocks off the road.”There are days spent in the one-room schoolhouse, and caring for loved ones' resting places on Decoration day. There are long, hot summer revival-time nights and Sundays listening to the tough, hard-nosed Preacher and quiet, star-filled nights coon hunting with childhood friends like Bobby. And interspersed with these, there are more sobering vignettes about wartime. Bobby’s brother is home with a bad leg and shell shock. And the draft system has begun:“Well looky here,” Daddy said. “They finally stopped volunteer enlistment. Says here the president has tolt folks that the Selective Service System has to be used to fetch recruits.”“Reckon folks’ll fight as don’t want to ?” Aunt Lois asked Daddy.“Put ‘em in a place where they’s people shooting at ‘em, and don’t matter much whether they want to or not. They will.”A book not only about a twelve-year old boy (turning thirteen) with a busy childhood, it is also a book about a time in America’s past that is forever gone:“Turned out the Gilmer County sheriff had resigned to go fight. Course, he could, him being awful young to begin with. Ed Rackley’s daddy had been sheriff, and when he suddenly died everybody reckoned he had trained Ed good enough to be sheriff, though Ed had barely reached eighteen.” Most of all, "The Christmas Quilt" is a story about Granny who never gives up looking for her son to come home. Her unflagging perseverance and spirit shine through this novel, teaching a young boy that what has to be done can be done.A poignant, touching story that reminds us all of what we most look for no matter where we are; a place to come home to.
it is written like country mountain people talk and it drove me crazy, so I quit

A mildly touching coming-of-age story. Good characters but the story got a little bogged down in the detailed descriptions of life during that era. Plus, the thick southern accents of the characters was a little too much at times. Still enjoyable, however.

1.5 Stars***I always like to read Christmas books around the holiday. This literally has the word in the title, but it didn't really center around it whatsoever. It really didn't even mention it until the end of the story. I wasn't expecting a terrific book. I just wanted a decent and quick read. This was neither of those because it was boring and I had to DRAG myself through the end. I wanted something that was just a good ol' country story that maybe dealt with quilting at Christmas back in the day. But what I got was just the daily happenings (which in the country in the 1940's wasn't much of nothin' ya hear) and several trips to the church. I didn't connect with any of the characters. And the story was stagnant from the get-go. If you like books that don't really go anywhere - this is for you. I'll give it the extra half-star because I did enjoy some of the author's writing style. I've seen country done better, but there were a few spots in the book where he captured things a bit more uniquely than others. Though it's not enough to earn your attention to read this al the way through. Trust me.
Book club, book 15, Nov. 2007, I did not read this yet, but I think mom has the book.

This is a sad, happy, inspiring story revolving around a close knit family living in a very different time than we are now and the events that lead up to the Christmas of 1942. You find out extremely early on what makes this particular Christmas so important and then the story proceeds to show you what transpires in the months before.The author tells the story from the main focal point of a 12, going on 13, year old boy. Times were so much different back then it was entertaining to try to picture the events as they were happening. There were quite a few sermons and things of that nature (not relating to Christmas) that I suppose I wasn't necessarily expecting as they took up a good bit of story time but they were good. The book was one that was predictable in the sense that it told you what would happen at the end, so it was supposed to be and that really built up a bit of the emotional turmoil you, the reader, held on to, as you read. It was also very unpredictable at many different places so it had a terrific balance. This is one that tugs on the heartstrings a lot and may just remind some of their own youth or others of the stories they may have heard from their own older relatives while growing up. It's definitely worth reading and don't let the name get you, it doesn't have to be read at Christmas. It can be read and enjoyed any time of year!

A simple, southern tale of a boy coming of age in rural Georgia.This story had so many parallels to Cold Sassy Tree that I couldn't help but think of the work by Olive Ann Burns as I read this one: the setting of historical Georgia; the unkind-but-acclimatable slang and twang of the region and its people; the overbearing aunt always picking on the adolescent boy; the focus on a grandparent and that relation's private life; a water-downed version of the gospel intermingled into the plot. When the boy nearly got hit by a train, it was a little uncanny.However, this story had a different slant and slightly different feel - and plenty of sadness, what with two world wars and polio outbreaks and veterans returning home not the same men who'd left. The focus on a prodigal son's return also made for a different kind of story.I enjoyed the writing, and Granny's gentle wisdom, and the red clay of Georgia that seemed like a character unto itself. All in all, a good, even-paced read - very enjoyable, and I look forward to checking out the author's other work.

This was a very sweet coming of age story. A young boy, a member of a poor farming community, spends his twelfth year doing chores, getting his first crush, having his best friend contract polio, watching his grandmother slowly wither due to heart disease, and waiting for his uncle to come home from an idyllic life in Detroit. The author manages to put magic and appreciation into the smallest of activities, making the entire book a study in valuing the little things in life. I actually quite enjoyed the dialogue being in the dialect of the northern Georgia rural areas, though I know that some would find it annoying and difficult to read. I felt that the language really transported me into the story the descriptions were vivid and the characters enchanting.

[close] I really enjoyed reading this story about a family in the northern mountains of Georgia in 1942, told from the point of view of a 13 year old boy living with his dad and Granny. I think what I enjoyed the most was the look at life back then and there -- a much simpler life in many ways, more difficult in other ways. I loved all of the Southern dialect and the portrayal of Southern life in the 1940s. It definitely wasn't a real page-turner, and the ending was a bit predictable (although not completely), but I still really enjoyed reading this book.

I started this in the beauty shop while I was waiting for my hair to color. I got about 30 pages in, realized that I hated it too much to read on, flipped to the back, and everything that I thought from the beginning played itself out at the end. Or near the end. I didn't even finish the last group of pages because it was time to wash my hair. It was totally sappy with the worst dialogue that I've read in many a day. A few pages and I wanted to slap somebody, anybody. Don't bother checking it out of the library.

This book wasn't exactly what I was expecting it to be, based on the title, but in the end, the title is perfect. It's a fictional memoir of a young boy growing up in Georgia, therefore written heavily in Southern dialect. Being from the South myself, reading the book made me aware of phrases and ways of speaking that seem different when you read them, but never questioned growing up there. It would have been interesting for that reason alone. It was a great story too, though.

Somewhat slow moving, this story of a young boy and his family wouldn't be the same if it was filled with fast paced action. A boy and his family suffer through losses and love as they live with very little and work hard at what they do have. I thoroughly enjoyed the slow pace and entertaining quality of this well written tale. Numerous characters depicted throughout this story are so very different but living side by side and always there for one another when times are challenging.

Written in the voice of a twelve-year-old boy in 1942, I initially found this book hard to follow. There was more discussion about the boy's activities than held my attention. The story became more interesting as the dying grandmother worked to finish her son's Christmas Quilt on time. The family drama in the remote mountain town seemed realistic. I did enjoy the closing chapters that revealed satisfying surprises and outcomes.

I read this book probably 6 years ago and I didn't remember it very well, so re-read it. It's a great book of family values. The story is told from the perspective of a young boy living with his grandmother and father, his mother having died earlier. The grandmother hasn't seen one of her sons in a long, long time. In fact, the boy has never met him. She feels sure he will come home for Christmas and prepares a Christmas quilt for him. The ending is told in the first chapter!

An incredible read - gentle, moving, well-paced. I like it so much that my husband (who rarely reads fiction) picked it up and read it in a few days, too. This book gives a neat view of post WWII in the mountains of Northern Georgian; a little like Mayberry without the goofiness. We see a young boy become a teenager, and grow into manhood.I won't spoil it with any details, but I count the serendipitous way this book came into our home a real blessing. Read it yourself!

This book is a story of a family in the mountains of North Georgia. Sunday dinners at Granny's, picking blackberries, tending the garden, swimming in the town river with friends and a revival meeting are some of the settings. Granny is the glue that holds everyone together. Very true to life characters in this book. Easy to relate to them. I recommend this book to everyone.

I really enjoyed this book. It was sweet without putting one into a diabetic coma. Sentimental, yet dealt with the reality of living in rural Georgia in the 1940's. The back cover says "reminiscent of TV's Walton family", and I would have to agree with that. I felt it had substance to it, and wasn't just another Christmas story.

This is a story about a North Georgia mountain family and the community they lived in during the 1940s. Their world was family, church and community and they believed in doing the right thing in the best way they could. The main character is a young boy growing up listening to stories told by his father and his grandmother.

I enjoyed this book completely. The auhor's use of the North Carolina jargon enhanced the story and made it feel real. It made me laugh; it made me cry. I fell in love with the characters and was sad when the book ended and severed my "relationship" with these humble people. Highly recommend.

Boring. The entire book was about grandmother waiting for her long gone son to come home for Christmas. She (and the family) made a quilt for his return. Like the prodigal son. Too "churchy" for me and I like church.

I recommended this book to some of you last year. I just had to read it again. I love it! It's about a family living in the mountains of North Georgia in the 1940's. Very warm and touching. I'll bet if you read it you will be glad you did!

This was such a sweet book! It is about a family living in a rural community in Georgia in the 1940's. So fun to get a snapshot of this family's day-to-day life and of the culture in general. Very heartwarming book.

I picked this book up from the library shelf without knowing anything about it just because I was looking for a feel-good Christmas story. It is simple and predictable, but sweet. I particularly enjoyed the imagery - sometimes I felt that I had jumped right into the story with the characters.
I really liked this book. The characters in it reminded me of my grandparents. It was just a good, old-fashioned Christmas book.
A wonderful story of life, love, and loss set in northern Georgia, 1942; seen through a young boy's eyes.
I didn't finish it - I couldn't get past the way the author wrote the characters' dialect. It was repetitive and annoying and I couldn't get over it.
I finished the book "The Christmas Quilt" by Thomas J. Davis the same day that I started it. I enjoyed this book.
This book takes place in 1942 Carolina. The setting was great, the story was good, but the dialect drove me nuts.Task 50 part 3 Memories
This is actually at least a four star story--but I confess I deducted a star because of the sad event near the end. It's a wonderful book, and I really enjoyed reading it.

description: A book of love, hope, and warmth, The Christmas Quiltis about home, about roots, and about "one small snowflake following another, settling on the ground soft like a kiss from heaven, covering Smoky Hollow like a blanket of grace that shines white with goodness."Reminiscent of Lee Smith'sOral Historyor ofCold Sassy Treeby Olive Ann Burns for its intimate portrayal of mountain life in an earlier day, The Christmas Quiltis a compelling and tender account of seven months in the lives of the members of a family in the mountains of north Georgia. It will endear you not only to its storyline, but to the pictures it paints of Sunday dinners, of picking blackberries, of running train tracks, of a revival meeting, and of Granny creating a quilt for her long-absent son."
title: The Christmas Quilt
